patient_information: A 74-year-old Japanese man with a history of cerebral infarction (without neurological sequelae), hypertension, and ulcerative colitis. He is taking antiplatelet, antihypertensive medicine, and adalimumab (TNF-alpha Blocker) subcutaneously every 2 weeks.
chief_complaint: Fever, joint pain, headache, nausea, and drowsiness over the past 5 days.
history_of_present_illness: The patient presented with fever, joint pain, headache, and nausea over the past 5 days. He appeared unwell and drowsy, also exhibiting impaired consciousness and respiratory distress.
exposure_and_epidemiology: He lives in a suburb of a city in Kyushu district, southwestern Japan. He is retired and does grape farming occasionally, which gives him opportunities to encounter wild animals such as boars and deer. He has no recent history of overseas travel.
vitals: Body temperature: 37°C (98.6°F), Pulse rate: 101 bpm, Blood pressure: 120/70 mmHg, SpO2: 96% with 7L oxygen, Respiratory rate: 32 breaths per minute.
physical_exam: Patient looks unwell and drowsy. Chest examination is normal. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) on arrival is 13/15 (E3V4M6). Livedo reticularis bilaterally on his lower extremities was noted, but no other rash was seen. His left inguinal lymph node was enlarged.
labs_and_diagnostics: WBC: 5.3 x 10^9/L (normal), Haemoglobin: 17.7 g/dL (elevated), Platelets: 90 x 10^9/L (low), AST: 413 U/L (elevated), ALT: 95 U/L (elevated), LDH: 1025 U/L (elevated), CK: 7442 U/L (elevated), CK-MB: 41 U/L (elevated), CRP: 0.1 mg/dL (normal). SFTS virus PCR on blood serum was positive.
differential_diagnosis: Pneumonia, meningitis, infective endocarditis, tick- and mite-borne infectious diseases including Japanese spotted fever (Rickettsia japonica), scrub typhus (Orientia tsutsugamushi), and severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome (SFTS).
management_and_clinical_course: The patient was immediately intubated and admitted to the intensive care unit. Meropenem and vancomycin were initiated for possible bacterial sepsis. After SFTS virus PCR returned positive and no bacterial infection was identified, antibiotics were discontinued. Despite adequate fluid administration and supportive therapies, he experienced worsening respiratory condition and protracted hypotension for a week. Noradrenaline was initiated, followed by hydrocortisone 200 mg/day for non-responsive septic shock. He then showed gradual improvement. His platelet count decreased to 65 x 10^9/L on day 4 but recovered. CK levels were highest on admission and normalized by day 7. He was extubated on day 12 and discharged on day 35 without sequelae.
